Back in 2022 Vampire Survivors did not invent its genre but it did give it a major boost in popularity, now there are numerous Survivor-likes everywhere.
But back thern  its content was pretty damn anemic.

A big part of the major content that has been introduced since then can be found in the DLCs, but there were also plenty of updates to the base game.

The result of this is that there is at least something to do in this game unlike many lesser titles.
There is a sizable number of unlocks, a clear progression path of what to do and unlock next, many different stages with some unique gimmicks and plenty of hidden secrets.

If you go for full completion you will be busy for a while and even if you arent then the variety can be entertaining for a while.

That said, this is still the game that survivor-likes come from and therefor does not innovate upon the genre.
For the most part it really is just the same eternal loop of pickung up a few weapons and upgrading them until the entire screen explodes and the game becomes hard to look at.
You can do this with many different characters and weapons now but the result and gameplay will always be the same.

But there is a reason this genre got popular and its 5 bucks without a sale, just give it a try, you will at least get a few hours out of it.

It's fun. It's never ending. It's a story. It's a never ending story. And it's fun.

The controls are so simple, making the game play super accessible even for older people and those with differing needs. There's also a good amount of variety in terms of characters, weapons, environments, and so on. You need to get used to dying. And dying. And dying some more, because that's just how the game works. Also, don't expect to find too many vampires. They're basically in another coffin. You wouldn't have heard of it.

Really, it's just nice to have a simplistic game where you can choose ahead of time how long you've got to play (i.e. 15 minute stages, 30 minute stages) and just go in to wreak some havoc.

It's also pretty fun to explore all the weapon and enhancement combinations, figure out which ones work for your preferred play style. Challenge yourself with the weaker combinations and evolutions or if you're in the mood to simply kick butt, you can pick the good stuff and kill, kill, kill.

Anyway, so nice that I can put this game away for months, come back and play a few rounds and just enjoy it. No stories I have to remember. No character arcs to concern myself with. Don't have to relearn the controls. Don't have to relearn how to play. Just pick it up and go have fun. At the end of the day, hard to beat that.

Graphics are obviously old school style pixel art, but with massive numbers of sprites, like if you had a super computer running a Genesis or SNES back in the day. Mostly. I like the aesthetic. Music is also pretty cool.

Overall, I recommend this. It's not for everybody, but it's so inexpensive to buy, there's very little risk. Also, I"m not a DLC person, but I got the DLC on sale for this and so far, it's all fun. Really adds a lot more variety.

First off, don't trust my current time on the game, I've owned Vampire Survivors on console for over a year at this point and i'd say this is a perfect example of a game I'd define by the phrase "Just one more run." The brain that thought you just had a little time to kill will be baffled at how the hell four hours have passed, you've died fifteen times, and you know you can somehow get more pew pew death lights flashing all over the screen so you start another run all over again.

The developer took the already decent sauce of the multidirectional shooter, set your attacks to auto in set patterns, gave it some rogue-lite passive upgrades and unlocks, and added some bizarre secret blend of spices that that makes the monkey brain treat it like crack. And they're STILL cooking with the recent release of co-op. For five dollars this is a worthwhile pickup for pretty much anyone, even better if you've got a friend or two to join in.
